div1.ab: Analyze Response to the communication of our ambassador near Saint- Liège, relative to the facts of treatment of us that would be Introduced to the Côte d'Ivoire
The Governor of the Côte d'Ivoire, to Mister Minister of the Colonies in Paris
div1.p: Mister Minister, By dispatch of last June 15th, you had wanted to transmit to me the copy of a letter by which our ambassador near Saint-Siège informs that his attention was called by cardinal Rampolla on a report in which the apostolic Prefect of the Côte d'Ivoire indicates an increase of the treatment of blacks, masacres of slave and human sacrifices that are practiced to the doors of Grand-Bassam.

I have the honor of informing you that following this communication I called P. Ray, apostolic prefect, and I prayed to him to supply me with some explanations on the facts that could have motivated on his part the appreciations also manifestly exagerated, not to say inexact. The result of the formal declarations that he made to me throughout our interview, that it is not to his knowledge that the human sacrifices were produced since he

since he has been in the colony; that he never incidentally in any letter talked of increase in the treatment of blacks, or masacres of slaves. The Apostolic Prefect would be narrow-minded, in a letter addressed to the Superior of the Society of African Missions of which the headquarters is in Lyon, j recount that in Memni, village situated in the Attié at about 70 kilometers to the North of Grand. Bassam, two indigenous, threatened to be put to death for an unknown motive, would be missionaries in the house of the missionnary, and would have escaped those who were pursuing them that thanks to the intervention of this last. The fact would happen around the month of august of last year. P. Ray added that he had written that which preceeds without attaching the least importance, and he expressed to me his regrets that one exagerated the terms of his letter.

I did not remark to him in the least the bit of correction of his conduct, and invited him to show henceforth more caution in his correspondences with his ecclesiastic superiors. I made the promise. I have place to believe that P. Ray is guilty of my observations, and that he will no longer expose himself, by the letters written carelessly
and warned a time not very far away where these odious costumes will have definitively ceased./.
